awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2020: Connecting comparative, genomic, and evolutionary ecology factors to extreme mammalian longevity
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2020, Broadening Participation of Groups Under-represented in Biology. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology. In mammals, maximum lifespan increases with body mass such that large species tend to live longer than smaller species. Bats are a unique exception to this Rule of Life and several species live much longer than expected given their body mass. Extreme longevity, as seen in several species of bats, is facilitated by mechanisms that repair cell and tissue damage, maintain immune system function, and prevent the emergence of mutations that cause aging-associated degenerative disease such as cancer. Evolutionary theory proposes that the evolution of flight, nocturnal behavior, and in some species, hibernation released bats from sources of mortality such as predation, reshaping life history to allow greater investment in mechanisms that allow bats to remain reproductive and healthy at older life stages. This project will test this theory using genomic analyses to explore the basis of unexpected longevity in pairs of closely related bat species with divergent lifespans and life history strategies. The fellow will also explore how mortality caused by white-nose syndrome, an emergent disease in North American bats, is reshaping life history and thus investment in the mechanisms that facilitate healthy aging among bat populations. This project will test longstanding theories of aging and evaluate the impact of disease mortality on aging in a natural population. To promote broader participation in biology, the fellow will highlight research by scientists from underrepresented groups in a seminar series, providing successful role models to inspire students to remain in science.

Evolutionary Theory suggests that this Rule of Life reflects physiological tradeoffs between maintenance and reproduction, while Damage Theory proposes that aging results from an accumulation of wear and tear. This project will test competing theories of aging and elucidate genotype-to-phenotype connections and gene regulatory networks that underlie extreme longevity using 1) comparative phylogenetics to test whether extreme longevity evolved through an adaptive model of trait evolution corresponding to variation in extrinsic mortality (Evolutionary Theory) or to metabolic rate variation (Damage Theory) or following a random-walk model; 2) comparative genomics to explore the molecular correlates of extreme longevity in several bat lineages; and 3) a search for signatures of divergence between epigenetic age and chronological age among Myotis lucifugus populations impacted by high disease-mediated extrinsic mortality from white-nose syndrome. Further, the fellow will establish a seminar series at SUNY Stony Brook that highlights early-career researchers from underrepresented groups in biology. This effort will increase the visibility of underrepresented scientists, allow early-career researchers to establish collaborations at a leading research university, and combat the attrition of underrepresented graduate students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: Maximum lifespan varies more than 200-fold among mammals and scales with other life history traits including body size. Some small mammals, such as bats, have exceptionally long lifespans and present a unique system in which to test hypotheses related to theories of aging. Competing theories suggest that aging is not “programmed”, but a byproduct of declining reproductive output with age (Evolutionary Theory), or that aging results from an accumulation of molecular and cellular wear-and-tear (Damage or Error Theory). This project leveraged life history trait data for 644 mammals, and reference-quality genomes from pairs of bats with exceptionally high and low longevity quotients. In order to reduce potential confounding factors related to evolutionary divergence, each pair included members of the same family, and when possible, members of the same genus.

The project consisted of three major objectives:

  • Describe mammalian lifespan~body size allometries using comparative phylogenomics

  • Test hypotheses about the evolution of maximum lifespan within Chiroptera using comparative genomics

  • Search for signatures of divergence between biological and chronological age (i.e., epigenetic age acceleration) among bat populations exposed to Pseudogymnoascus destructans fungus


Objective 1 is partially complete and is still underway. We modeled the evolution of maximum lifespan in the context of its relationship to body size for 644 mammals spanning 23 orders. Our results describe 22 distinct allometric relationships. The timing of these allometric shifts correspond to higher mean sea levels, indicative of warmer periods in Earth’s climate. This analysis, in support of newly emerged literature, bolsters the conclusion that the evolutionary lability of life history traits shapes rapid adaptation to environmental change.

Objective 2 was successfully completed. The project leveraged seven new genome assemblies generated by Bat1K including Saccopteryx leptura (lesser sac-winged bat), Saccopteryx bilineata (greater sac-winged bat), Myotis nigricans (black myotis bat), Diphylla ecaudata (hairy-legged vampire bat), Antrozous pallidus (pallid bat), Tadarida brasiliensis (Mexican free-tailed bat), and Phyllostomus hastatus (greater spear-nosed bat). Comparative study of 23 bat and 7 non-bat genome assemblies resulted in the preparation of one major publication which describes signatures of molecular evolution among protein-coding genes associated with the nine hallmarks of aging. Our results support the principal finding that long-lived bats have not convergently evolved a shared set of geroprotective mechanisms. Rather, each species has evolved a highly individualized “pathway” to long lifespan with evidence of molecular evolution enriching four processes -- DNA repair, chromatin remodeling, ubiquitin-proteasome system, and inflammatory response. 

Lama accepted a tenure-track position, ending the award period before pursuing Objective 3. However, elements of Objective 3 have been proposed under a National Science Foundation Building Research Capacity proposal. The project was central to the development of an independent line of research pursued by Lama as a tenure-track faculty member at Smith College in the Department of Biological Sciences. Lama’s research group uses integrative and multi-omic approaches to study the evolutionary processes underlying population vulnerability, resilience, and response, particularly in the context of rapid environmental change. 

Broader impacts: PIs Lama and Dàvalos hosted a successful seminar series at SUNY Stony Brook highlighting the research and diversity, equity, inclusion, and justice (DEIJ) contributions of thirteen early-career researchers from underrepresented backgrounds in science. Lama incorporated three graduate students in efforts to analyze gene family evolution and signatures of diversifying selection in bats in comparison to other mammals. Six undergraduate students were incorporated in the establishment and assay of primary fibroblast cell cultures for functional validations. One undergraduate student completed the immersive Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program under Lama’s mentorship. Finally, the award supported work associated with six publications. PI Lama delivered twelve invited seminars at a variety of academic institutions.

1. Moreno Santillan DD, Lama TM, Gutierrez Guerrero YT, et al. Large-scale sampling reveals unique immunity and metabolic adaptations in bats. Molecular Ecology. 2021;30(23):6449–6467. doi:10.1111/mec.16027

2. Dahn HA, Mountcastle J, Balacco J, et al. Benchmarking ultra-high molecular weight DNA preservation methods for long-read and long-range sequencing. Gigascience. 2022;0:1–13. doi:10.1093/gigascience/giac068

3. Forester BR, Lama TM. The role of genomics in the future of Endangered Species Act decision-making. In: Organ JF, Baier LE, eds. The Codex of the Endangered Species Act: The Next Fifty Years. Lanham, MD: Rowman & Littlefield; 2023:159–186. doi:10.32942/osf.io/b6rf4

4. Forester BR, Lama TM, Kardos M. A landmark environmental law looks ahead: Updating practice for the genomic era. Science. 2023;382(6677):1348–55. doi:10.1126/science.adn3245

5. Morales A, Dong Y, Brown T, et al. Reference-quality bat genomes illuminate adaptations to viral tolerance and disease resistance. Nature. 2024. doi:10.21203/rs.3.rs-2557682/v1

6. Vazquez JM, Lauterbur ME, Mottaghinia S, et al. Extensive longevity and DNA virus-driven adaptation in nearctic Myotis bats. bioRxiv. 2024. doi:10.1101/2024.10.10.617725
